contentrichtext.text: [[File:Valentine radiguet jean.jpg|thumb|300px|Valentine Hugo with [[Raymond Radiguet]] (center) and [[Jean Hugo]] (right), 1921]] '''Valentine Hugo''' (1887 – 1968) was a French artist. She was born Valentine Gross in [[Boulogne-sur-Mer]] and died in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Valentine Hugo: An Inventory of Her Papers in the Carlton Lake Collection|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/uthrc/00293/hrc-00293.html|publisher=Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center|accessdate=February 15, 2012}}</ref> Valentine studied painting in Paris, and in 1919 married French artist [[Jean Hugo (Artist, 1894 - 1984)|Jean Hugo]] (1894–1984), great-grandson of [[Victor Hugo]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Lake|first=Carlton|title=Confessions of a Literary Archaeologist|year=1990|publisher=New Directions|location=New York|isbn=0-8112-1130-4|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0MXqeHaxXj4C&pg=PA90&dq=%22valentine+hugo%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Tew7T9TFLsrL0QHV84ijCw&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22valentine%20hugo%22&f=false|page=90}}</ref> She collaborated with him on ballet designs including ''[[Les mariés de la tour Eiffel]]'' (1921), and in 1926 executed 24 wood engravings after maquettes by Jean Hugo for [[Jean Cocteau]]'s production of ''Roméo et Juliette''. She met the surrealists around 1928 and actively participated in the movement between 1930 and 1936. The foremost illustrator of [[Paul Éluard]]'s work, she first exhibited with the surrealists in the [[Salon des Surindépendants]] of 1933. Her many illustrations include, * [[Comte de Lautréamont]]'s ''[[Les Chants de Maldoror]]'' (1933) * [[Achim von Arnim]]'s ''Contes bizarres'' (1933) * [[Arthur Rimbaud]]'s ''Les Poètes de sept ans'' (1939) * [[Paul Éluard]]'s ''Les Animaux et leurs hommes'' (1937) * [[Roger Peyrefitte]]'s ''[[Les amitiés particulières]]'' (1946) A retrospective exhibition of her work was held at the Centre Culturel Thibaud de Champagne, [[Troyes]], in 1977. Other exhibitions of her work have been at: Tenerife (1935), Copenhagen (1935), New York (1937), Tokyo (1937). ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.leninimports.com/valentine_hugo.html Short biography] {{Authority control|VIAF=68930456}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Hugo, Valentine | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Surrealist artist | DATE OF BIRTH = 1887 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Boulogne-sur-Mer | DATE OF DEATH = 1968 | PLACE OF DEATH = Paris }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hugo, Valentine}} [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century engravers]] [[Category:French illustrators]] [[Category:French engravers]] [[Category:Surrealist artists]] {{France-artist-stub}}
